Transcription for 2062321

A

Next we come on to the Hunslet which was used underground to all supplies. It was
used to take men underground. It would be bringing the men out. It would be fitted
with a diesel engine. You couldn't fit a petrol engine. There'd be too much
danger in gas. Diesel was totally enclosed and was quite safe underground. Providing the
exhaust was long enough and muffled. To your right there's a lump of steel that
was a steam hammer. This came from Coygnant Collery to Blaenant in 1968.
When it was in commission in Coygnant the anvil that you see next to it would
have been actually underneath the hammer and protruding through this oblong hole
in the hammer. And the hammer would have been steam operated. You see the steam
engine on the left. This would have worked the hammer up and down for shaping
the steel.
Large sections of steel.

B

Next we come on to the Hunslet which was used underground to all supplies. It was used to take
men underground. It would be bringing the men out. It would be fitted with a diesel engine.
You couldn't fit a petrol engine. There'd be too much danger in gas. Diesel was totally enclosed
and was quite safe underground providing the exhaust was long enough unmuffled. To your right
there's a lump of steel that was a steam hammer. This came from Coignant collier to Blindant
in 1968. When it was in commission in Coignant the anvil that you see next to it would have been
actually underneath the hammer and protruding through the oblong hole in the hammer and the hammer would
have been steam operated. You see the steam engine on the left. This would have worked the hammer up
and down for shaping large sections of steel.

C

Next we come onto the Hunslet which was used underground to all supplies. It was used to take men underground. It would be bringing the men out. It would be fitted with a diesel engine. You couldn't fit a petrol engine. There'd be too much danger in gas.
Diesel was totally enclosed and was quite safe underground, providing the exhaust was long enough and muffled.
To your right there's a lump of steel that was a steam hammer. This came from Coignant Colliery to Blind Ant in 1968.
When it was in commission in Coignant, the anvil that you see next to it would have been actually underneath the hammer and protruding through the oblong hole in the hammer.
The hammer would have been steam operated. You see the steam engine on the left. This would have worked the hammer up and down for shaping large sections of steel.
